title: 107_s2576
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Northern Rio Grande National Heritage Area Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that northern New Mexico has a unique combination of cultures, history, and natural resources, with broad support for establishing a National Heritage Area to preserve and interpret these resources. Establishing a National Heritage Area in northern New Mexico would help preserve its unique cultural, historical, and natural resources through research, interpretation programs, and community involvement. The Northern Rio Grande National Heritage Area is established in New Mexico, encompassing Santa Fe, Rio Arriba, and Taos counties. The management entity for the heritage area is the non-profit corporation Northern Rio Grande National Heritage Area, Inc. The management entity for the Northern Rio Grande National Heritage Area must develop a management plan within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should involve affected communities, governments, and the public, and include recommendations for conservation, funding, resources, and educational programs. The management entity for the Northern Rio Grande National Heritage Area must develop a management plan within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should involve affected communities, governments, and the public, and include interpretive programs, coordination of programs, and periodic reviews to ensure eligibility for Federal funding. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days, providing reasons for disapproval and recommendations for revisions. The management entity must submit recommendations for revisions to the management plan to the Secretary for approval. The entity has the authority to provide grants and technical assistance to carry out the plan. Duties include prioritizing plan actions, coordinating with tribal and local governments on land use policies, promoting economic viability, and assisting governments and non-profit organizations. The management entity in the heritage area can assist local and tribal governments and non-profit organizations in establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational resources, increasing public awareness, restoring historic structures, and other appropriate actions. Federal funds received cannot be used to acquire real property. The management entity in the heritage area must hold public meetings annually and submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and grants made. All records related to the expenditure of Federal funds must be available for audit. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to develop and implement the management plan for the heritage area, prioritizing actions that conserve natural, cultural, and historical resources. Additionally, the Secretary must give priority to educational and recreational opportunities consistent with the area's values. SEC. 7. SAVINGS PROVISIONS.

    This Act does not affect the authority of governments to regulate privately owned lands or grant the management entity any authority over them.

SEC. 8. SUNSET.

    No grants or financial assistance can be provided under this Act after September 30, 2017.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 is authorized to carry out this Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share of costs not to exceed 50 percent.
